Digital Logic Design.description: This course covers stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.
Digital Logic Design.name: Chemistry 1

Digital Logic Design.description: Students will participate in laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2045. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Chemistry 1 Laboratory

Digital Logic Design.description: This foundation course is an introduction to engineering and addresses: ethics and professional responsibility, creative thinking, software and calculator techniques, time and project management, and technical report presentation and writing. Students will have opportunities to interact with engineering professionals. In the combined lab, teams will build and test various devices and report findings on paper, in verbal presentations, and by using various computer applications.
Digital Logic Design.name: Introduction to Engineering

Digital Logic Design.description: This course focuses on codes of ethics and moral reasoning, ethics and professionalism, the impact of engineering and technology problems/solutions/mistakes, engineering and technology as social experimentation, professional responsibilities and rights. Environmental and global issues are also discussed.
Digital Logic Design.name: Ethics

Digital Logic Design.description: This course focuses on the principal elements of writing clearly, efficiently and effectively. Logical arguments, building research skills and developing critical thinking through reading, writing and discussion are also presented. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: English Composition 1: Expository and Argumentative Writing

Digital Logic Design.description: This course is an introduction to analytic geometry; limits; continuity; differentiation of algebraic, trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions; applications of the derivative; inverse trigonometric functions; differentials; introduction to integration; and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
Digital Logic Design.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1

Digital Logic Design.description: This course is an introduction to computational thinking and the art of computer programming. Students will learn fundamental programming concepts and systematic design techniques. They will use them to write programs that computationally solve and reduce problems. At the end of the course, students will be able to use a programming language without focusing on the language specifics. No prior programming background is required and a working knowledge of high school level algebra is expected. This course is a prerequisite for all subsequent programming courses and is designed for all majors at both colleges.
Digital Logic Design.name: Introduction to Computation and Programming

Digital Logic Design.description: This foundation course provides a first look at engineering design and focuses on creativity, teamwork, communication, leadership, and work across engineering disciplines. Students will participate in a design-build-test project. Teams are required to give verbal and written technical and managerial reports.
Digital Logic Design.name: Introduction to Engineering Design

Digital Logic Design.description: This course focuses on the forms, formats, and genres of business, government, professional, and technical communication. Students are given opportunities to practice creating proposals, reports, applications, and resumes. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Technical Writing

Digital Logic Design.description: Techniques of integration; applications of integration; differentiation and integration of inverse trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions; sequences and series are presented in this class.
Digital Logic Design.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2

Digital Logic Design.description: This is the first of a two-semester sequence of physics for technology and engineering. The course covers Newtonian mechanics and includes motion, vectors, Newton's laws, work and conservation of energy, systems of particles, collisions, equilibrium, oscillations, thermodynamics and waves.
Digital Logic Design.name: Physics 1

Digital Logic Design.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2048 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1 provides practical applications of Newtonian mechanics.
Digital Logic Design.name: Physics 1 Laboratory

Digital Logic Design.description: This is an intermediate programming course designed for students with prior programming experience in any language. It revises the fundamental programming concepts focusing on best practices in designing and writing efficient code. It also covers basic user-defined data types and the use of essential built-in data structures. After completing the course, students will have a solid command of computer programming and will be able to write medium-sized computer code.
Digital Logic Design.name: Computer Programming 1

Digital Logic Design.description: This lecture-lab combined course covers the basic analysis of linear circuits.  Topics include electrical quantities, network laws and theorems, steady state and transient analysis for circuits.  Computer-aided analysis is also covered.
Digital Logic Design.name: Circuits 1

Digital Logic Design.description: This course covers solid analytic geometry, vectors, partial derivatives and multiple integrals.
Digital Logic Design.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 3

Digital Logic Design.description: The second of a two-semester sequence of physics for scientists and engineers. Content includes Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Digital Logic Design.name: Physics 2

Digital Logic Design.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2049 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2 illustrates the practical applications of Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Digital Logic Design.name: Physics 2 Laboratory

Digital Logic Design.description: This lecture-lab combined course introduces the fundamentals of transient state analysis; linear circuit analysis in frequency domain, sinusoidal steady-state analysis and power calculations, Laplace transform techniques, frequency response analysis, balanced three-phase circuits and two-port circuit analysis.
Digital Logic Design.name: Circuits 2

Digital Logic Design.description: The analysis and design of sequential logic circuits, combinational logic circuits, and feedback circuits are covered in this course. Additional topics include Boolean algebra, Boolean functions, number systems, minimizations, binary arithmetic, k-maps, combinational circuit synthesis, combinational medium scale integrated (MSI) logic circuits, sequential logic, sequential MSI logic circuits and synchronous state machine design.
Digital Logic Design.name: Digital Logic Design

Digital Logic Design.description: This course discusses logic, sets, functions, algorithms and complexity, integers and algorithms, mathematical reasoning and induction, counting principles, permutations and combinations, discrete probability, advanced counting techniques and inclusion-exclusion.
Digital Logic Design.name: Discrete Mathematics

Digital Logic Design.description: The relationship between differential equations and initial conditions to physical problems in engineering, physics, technology and other applied areas is discussed. Students will be able to formulate, solve, and analyze the results of mathematical models of elementary physical problems and apply them. Topics include: first-order ordinary differential equations, theory of linear ordinary differential equations, solution of linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients, the Laplace transform and its application to solving linear ordinary differential equations.
Digital Logic Design.name: Differential Equations

Digital Logic Design.description: Introduction to the artistic experience through the examination of different ideas, approaches and purposes of art. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Art Appreciation

Digital Logic Design.description: This course is an introduction to the nature of philosophy, philosophical thinking, major intellectual movements in the history of philosophy, and specific problems in philosophy. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Introduction to Philosophy

Digital Logic Design.description: The course introduces program run-time analysis and algorithm design and analysis. Topics include: data abstraction principals, serial and parallel data structures, linked lists, graphs, trees, divide and conquer algorithms, greedy algorithms, and linear programming.
Digital Logic Design.name: Data Structures & Algorithms

Digital Logic Design.description: Continuous-time and discrete-time systems analysis, focusing on linear time-invariant (LTI) systems and the classification of these systems is presented in this course. Convolution and its application to LTI systems, the Laplace, Fourier, and z transforms, the Fourier series and their application to the analysis of LTI systems will also be presented. Industry applications will be a specific focus.
Digital Logic Design.name: Systems and Signals

Digital Logic Design.description: This is a design course sequence for students with at least junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Design 1

Digital Logic Design.description: This course covers probability, random variables, hypothesis testing, confidence interval estimation, small sample methods, correlation, simple linear regression, and nonparametric statistics.
Digital Logic Design.name: Statistics 1

Digital Logic Design.description: This course presents a survey of the emergence of modern America as an industrial and world power; the Progressive Era; WWI; the Great Depression and the New Deal; WW II; and the Cold War era. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: American History Since 1877

Digital Logic Design.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Digital Logic Design.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Digital Logic Design.description: An introduction to the basic principles, theories, and methods of psychology surveying the various areas of psychology.  This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: General Psychology

Digital Logic Design.description: This course provides an introduction to fundamental concepts in computer networks, including their design and implementation. Topics covered include all seven layers of OSI Reference Model, network protocols (providing reliability and congestion control), routing, and link access. Special attention is also paid to wireless networks and security.
Digital Logic Design.name: Introduction to Computer Networks

Digital Logic Design.description: This course focuses on the implementation of logic devices, MOSFET's, and BJT's. Students will analyze logic families including NMOS, CMOS, and TTL. The fundamentals of digital memory circuits are also covered.
Digital Logic Design.name: Digital Electronics

Digital Logic Design.description: This is a design course for students with junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Design 2

Digital Logic Design.description: Classroom theory will be integrated with a participatory and experiential learning and work experience in business, industry, government and other technology-oriented areas of student interest. Evaluation by work supervisor is required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal, and a post-internship report are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Internship

Digital Logic Design.description: This course discusses planning, controlling, and evaluating technology and engineering projects. Topics include modeling, project organization, risk analysis, technical forecasting, time and cost estimation and accommodation, and resource allocation and leveling. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required.
Digital Logic Design.name: Engineering & Technology Project Management

Digital Logic Design.description: This course is an introduction to the internal operation, terminal characteristics, and material physics of semi-conductors. Transistors, diode models and applications are also discussed. Principles of semiconductor devices and microelectronic circuits will be examined, along with the characteristics of diodes, multi-junction devices, metal oxide semiconductors and Field Effect Transistor based devices.
Digital Logic Design.name: Electronic Devices

Digital Logic Design.description: In this course you will study digital signal processing, sampling and quantization, A/D & D/A converters, discrete time systems, convolution, z-transforms, transfer functions, digital filter realizations, fast Fourier transforms and analog & digital filter design.
Digital Logic Design.name: Digital Signal Processing

Digital Logic Design.description: This course covers a top-down approach to computer design. Topics include Computer architecture, introduction to assembly language programming and machine language set design. Computer organization, logical modules, CPU, memory and I/O units, instruction cycles, the data path and control unit, hardwiring and microprogramming are also covered.
Digital Logic Design.name: Computer Architecture and Organization

Digital Logic Design.description: This course focuses on the design of digital electronic systems that meet application requirements while minimizing electrical power and energy needs. Hardware and software techniques for power management are presented in this course. The techniques covered have application in the Internet of Things (IoT), wearable electronics and energy harvesting electronics.
Digital Logic Design.name: Power Aware Design

Digital Logic Design.description: Topics discussed in this course include CMOS technology, MOSFET timing analysis, dynamic clocked logic, and layout design rules. Digital VLSI chip design is introduced. Computer-aided design software tools and elementary circuit design will be used. Cell library construction.
Digital Logic Design.name: VLSI Design

Digital Logic Design.description: The course covers object-oriented software engineering, the software development life cycle, system specification, software design patterns, and the methods of software measurement and estimation.
Digital Logic Design.name: Software Engineering

Digital Logic Design.description: The course will discuss microcomputers and microcontrollers and explore the subjects of memory addressing modes, instruction sets, central processing units / microprocessors, C and assembly language programming in the context of the course, debugging software and hardware, computer buses, interrupts, real-time events, memory, I/O, counters, timers and interfacing techniques.
Digital Logic Design.name: Microcomputers

Digital Logic Design.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital Logic Design.name: Design 3

Digital Logic Design.description: The objective of this course is to establish a foundation in two- and three-dimensional computer rendering algorithms and display devices. Topics included: Geometric transformations, homogeneous coordinates, anti-aliasing, color vision, ray tracing, surface modeling, texture mapping, polyhedral representations, and reflectance models.
Digital Logic Design.name: Computer Graphics

Digital Logic Design.description: Embedded Operating Systems or Real time operating systems are operating systems are designed to be compact, efficient, and reliable. Topics discussed include embedded architectures, interaction with devices, concurrency, real-time principles, implementation trade-offs, profiling and code optimization, embedded software.
Digital Logic Design.name: Embedded Operating Systems

Digital Logic Design.description: This course discusses server based operating systems which are deployed, administered and managed via remote locations. Emphasis is placed upon the hardware required for interconnecting digital devices for the purpose of enabling data communication through a network. Bus architectures, ports, network cards, cabling, routers, switches are also covered. Ensuring network reliability and optimizing network performance are presented.
Digital Logic Design.name: Distributed Information Systems

Digital Logic Design.description: The use of Structured Query Language (SQL) and broad knowledge of database design, implementation, and systems development are presented in this course. Emphasis is places upon data modeling concepts, approaches and techniques, and stages in database development processes (conceptual, logical and physical design).
Digital Logic Design.name: Database 1

Digital Logic Design.description: The course introduces concepts of parallel algorithms analysis and implementation. Topics covered: shared memory model, distributed memory model, concurrency, synchronization, message passing interface (MPI), heterogeneous parallel programming, GPU programming.
Digital Logic Design.name: Introduction to Parallel and Distributed Computing

Digital Logic Design.description: This course is an introduction to the internal operation, terminal characteristics, and material physics of semi-conductors. Transistors, diode models and applications are also discussed. Principles of semiconductor devices and microelectronic circuits will be examined, along with the characteristics of diodes, multi-junction devices, metal oxide semiconductors and Field Effect Transistor based devices.
Digital Logic Design.name: Electronic Devices

Digital Logic Design.description: The study of integrated multi-medium communication networks, examining multiplexing schematics, switching circuit networks and packet switching networks. Communication traffic characterization, delay, blocking analysis and queuing network analysis will also be discussed. The course will also explore routing protocols, protocol architectures, network architectures, layered connection management, network design, path dimensioning, dynamic routing, flow control, and random access algorithms. Additionally, protocols for error control, signaling, addressing, fault management, and security control will be covered.
Digital Logic Design.name: Digital Communication Systems

Digital Logic Design.description: This course covers the collaborative design and application of hybrid digital technology, devices, and systems.  Interfacing technologies, packaging electronics, and design considerations for modern devices, systems, and applications will also be discussed.  Some of the applications considered may include energy systems, mobile technology, sensor, networks, integrated rapid prototyping, and interfaces.
Digital Logic Design.name: Collaborative Digital and Hybrid System Design

Digital Logic Design.description: This course covers linear equations, matrices, vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues, and inner product spaces.
Digital Logic Design.name: Linear Algebra

Embedded System Design.description: This course covers stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.

Embedded System Design.description: This course covers the evaluation, design, and creation of mobile device software. Mobile application genres and the various development tools, languages, and environments are also covered.

Embedded System Design.description: Microprocessors as an embedded element of engineering systems are discussed in this course. Topics include hardware and software control, interface, command, networks, information, sensing, and display. Coursework focuses on the underlying mathematics, specifying performance of dynamic systems, system analysis, controller design and implementation on typical hardware platforms in C.

Embedded System Design.name: Linear Algebra

Machine Intelligence.description: This course covers stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.
Machine Intelligence.name: Chemistry 1

Machine Intelligence.description: Students will participate in laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2045. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Chemistry 1 Laboratory

Machine Intelligence.description: This foundation course is an introduction to engineering and addresses: ethics and professional responsibility, creative thinking, software and calculator techniques, time and project management, and technical report presentation and writing. Students will have opportunities to interact with engineering professionals. In the combined lab, teams will build and test various devices and report findings on paper, in verbal presentations, and by using various computer applications.
Machine Intelligence.name: Introduction to Engineering

Machine Intelligence.description: This course focuses on codes of ethics and moral reasoning, ethics and professionalism, the impact of engineering and technology problems/solutions/mistakes, engineering and technology as social experimentation, professional responsibilities and rights. Environmental and global issues are also discussed.
Machine Intelligence.name: Ethics

Machine Intelligence.description: This course focuses on the principal elements of writing clearly, efficiently and effectively. Logical arguments, building research skills and developing critical thinking through reading, writing and discussion are also presented. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: English Composition 1: Expository and Argumentative Writing

Machine Intelligence.description: This course is an introduction to analytic geometry; limits; continuity; differentiation of algebraic, trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions; applications of the derivative; inverse trigonometric functions; differentials; introduction to integration; and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
Machine Intelligence.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1

Machine Intelligence.description: This course is an introduction to computational thinking and the art of computer programming. Students will learn fundamental programming concepts and systematic design techniques. They will use them to write programs that computationally solve and reduce problems. At the end of the course, students will be able to use a programming language without focusing on the language specifics. No prior programming background is required and a working knowledge of high school level algebra is expected. This course is a prerequisite for all subsequent programming courses and is designed for all majors at both colleges.
Machine Intelligence.name: Introduction to Computation and Programming

Machine Intelligence.description: This foundation course provides a first look at engineering design and focuses on creativity, teamwork, communication, leadership, and work across engineering disciplines. Students will participate in a design-build-test project. Teams are required to give verbal and written technical and managerial reports.
Machine Intelligence.name: Introduction to Engineering Design

Machine Intelligence.description: This course focuses on the forms, formats, and genres of business, government, professional, and technical communication. Students are given opportunities to practice creating proposals, reports, applications, and resumes. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Technical Writing

Machine Intelligence.description: Techniques of integration; applications of integration; differentiation and integration of inverse trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions; sequences and series are presented in this class.
Machine Intelligence.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2

Machine Intelligence.description: This is the first of a two-semester sequence of physics for technology and engineering. The course covers Newtonian mechanics and includes motion, vectors, Newton's laws, work and conservation of energy, systems of particles, collisions, equilibrium, oscillations, thermodynamics and waves.
Machine Intelligence.name: Physics 1

Machine Intelligence.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2048 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1 provides practical applications of Newtonian mechanics.
Machine Intelligence.name: Physics 1 Laboratory

Machine Intelligence.description: This is an intermediate programming course designed for students with prior programming experience in any language. It revises the fundamental programming concepts focusing on best practices in designing and writing efficient code. It also covers basic user-defined data types and the use of essential built-in data structures. After completing the course, students will have a solid command of computer programming and will be able to write medium-sized computer code.
Machine Intelligence.name: Computer Programming 1

Machine Intelligence.description: This lecture-lab combined course covers the basic analysis of linear circuits.  Topics include electrical quantities, network laws and theorems, steady state and transient analysis for circuits.  Computer-aided analysis is also covered.
Machine Intelligence.name: Circuits 1

Machine Intelligence.description: This course covers solid analytic geometry, vectors, partial derivatives and multiple integrals.
Machine Intelligence.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 3

Machine Intelligence.description: The second of a two-semester sequence of physics for scientists and engineers. Content includes Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Machine Intelligence.name: Physics 2

Machine Intelligence.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2049 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2 illustrates the practical applications of Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Machine Intelligence.name: Physics 2 Laboratory

Machine Intelligence.description: This lecture-lab combined course introduces the fundamentals of transient state analysis; linear circuit analysis in frequency domain, sinusoidal steady-state analysis and power calculations, Laplace transform techniques, frequency response analysis, balanced three-phase circuits and two-port circuit analysis.
Machine Intelligence.name: Circuits 2

Machine Intelligence.description: The analysis and design of sequential logic circuits, combinational logic circuits, and feedback circuits are covered in this course. Additional topics include Boolean algebra, Boolean functions, number systems, minimizations, binary arithmetic, k-maps, combinational circuit synthesis, combinational medium scale integrated (MSI) logic circuits, sequential logic, sequential MSI logic circuits and synchronous state machine design.
Machine Intelligence.name: Digital Logic Design

Machine Intelligence.description: This course discusses logic, sets, functions, algorithms and complexity, integers and algorithms, mathematical reasoning and induction, counting principles, permutations and combinations, discrete probability, advanced counting techniques and inclusion-exclusion.
Machine Intelligence.name: Discrete Mathematics

Machine Intelligence.description: The relationship between differential equations and initial conditions to physical problems in engineering, physics, technology and other applied areas is discussed. Students will be able to formulate, solve, and analyze the results of mathematical models of elementary physical problems and apply them. Topics include: first-order ordinary differential equations, theory of linear ordinary differential equations, solution of linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients, the Laplace transform and its application to solving linear ordinary differential equations.
Machine Intelligence.name: Differential Equations

Machine Intelligence.description: Introduction to the artistic experience through the examination of different ideas, approaches and purposes of art. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Art Appreciation

Machine Intelligence.description: This course is an introduction to the nature of philosophy, philosophical thinking, major intellectual movements in the history of philosophy, and specific problems in philosophy. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Introduction to Philosophy

Machine Intelligence.description: The course introduces program run-time analysis and algorithm design and analysis. Topics include: data abstraction principals, serial and parallel data structures, linked lists, graphs, trees, divide and conquer algorithms, greedy algorithms, and linear programming.
Machine Intelligence.name: Data Structures & Algorithms

Machine Intelligence.description: Continuous-time and discrete-time systems analysis, focusing on linear time-invariant (LTI) systems and the classification of these systems is presented in this course. Convolution and its application to LTI systems, the Laplace, Fourier, and z transforms, the Fourier series and their application to the analysis of LTI systems will also be presented. Industry applications will be a specific focus.
Machine Intelligence.name: Systems and Signals

Machine Intelligence.description: This is a design course sequence for students with at least junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Design 1

Machine Intelligence.description: This course covers probability, random variables, hypothesis testing, confidence interval estimation, small sample methods, correlation, simple linear regression, and nonparametric statistics.
Machine Intelligence.name: Statistics 1

Machine Intelligence.description: This course presents a survey of the emergence of modern America as an industrial and world power; the Progressive Era; WWI; the Great Depression and the New Deal; WW II; and the Cold War era. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: American History Since 1877

Machine Intelligence.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Machine Intelligence.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Machine Intelligence.description: An introduction to the basic principles, theories, and methods of psychology surveying the various areas of psychology.  This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: General Psychology

Machine Intelligence.description: This course provides an introduction to fundamental concepts in computer networks, including their design and implementation. Topics covered include all seven layers of OSI Reference Model, network protocols (providing reliability and congestion control), routing, and link access. Special attention is also paid to wireless networks and security.
Machine Intelligence.name: Introduction to Computer Networks

Machine Intelligence.description: This course focuses on the implementation of logic devices, MOSFET's, and BJT's. Students will analyze logic families including NMOS, CMOS, and TTL. The fundamentals of digital memory circuits are also covered.
Machine Intelligence.name: Digital Electronics

Machine Intelligence.description: This is a design course for students with junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Design 2

Machine Intelligence.description: Classroom theory will be integrated with a participatory and experiential learning and work experience in business, industry, government and other technology-oriented areas of student interest. Evaluation by work supervisor is required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal, and a post-internship report are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Internship

Machine Intelligence.description: This course covers linear equations, matrices, vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues, and inner product spaces.
Machine Intelligence.name: Linear Algebra

Machine Intelligence.description: An overview of machine learning algorithms and their applications. Topics covered include: supervised and unsupervised learning, clustering and classification, linear and logistic regression, dimensionality reduction, support vector machines, anomaly detection.
Machine Intelligence.name: Machine Learning

Machine Intelligence.description: This course is an intermediate level computer programming course. It introduces intermediate programming concepts: Object-Oriented design principals, data abstraction, classes, polymorphism, inheritance, and basic algorithms. Students will acquire skills to solve larger projects and algorithmic problems with more efficient code.
Machine Intelligence.name: Computer Programming 2

Machine Intelligence.description: In this course you will study digital signal processing, sampling and quantization, A/D & D/A converters, discrete time systems, convolution, z-transforms, transfer functions, digital filter realizations, fast Fourier transforms and analog & digital filter design.
Machine Intelligence.name: Digital Signal Processing

Machine Intelligence.description: This course covers a top-down approach to computer design. Topics include Computer architecture, introduction to assembly language programming and machine language set design. Computer organization, logical modules, CPU, memory and I/O units, instruction cycles, the data path and control unit, hardwiring and microprogramming are also covered.
Machine Intelligence.name: Computer Architecture and Organization

Machine Intelligence.description: This course discusses planning, controlling, and evaluating technology and engineering projects. Topics include modeling, project organization, risk analysis, technical forecasting, time and cost estimation and accommodation, and resource allocation and leveling. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required.
Machine Intelligence.name: Engineering & Technology Project Management

Machine Intelligence.description: The course introduces how computers see and interpret the visual world and how this interpretation can be used to enhance game play experience. Topics covered: projections and coordinate systems, camera modeling, stereo vision, edge detection, filtering, segmentation, optical flow, motion vision, color vision, object representation, face recognition, object recognition.
Machine Intelligence.name: Computer Vision

Machine Intelligence.description: The course covers object-oriented software engineering, the software development life cycle, system specification, software design patterns, and the methods of software measurement and estimation.
Machine Intelligence.name: Software Engineering

Machine Intelligence.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Machine Intelligence.name: Design 3

Machine Intelligence.description: The course will discuss microcomputers and microcontrollers and explore the subjects of memory addressing modes, instruction sets, central processing units / microprocessors, C and assembly language programming in the context of the course, debugging software and hardware, computer buses, interrupts, real-time events, memory, I/O, counters, timers and interfacing techniques.
Machine Intelligence.name: Microcomputers

Machine Intelligence.description: The objective of this course is to establish a foundation in two- and three-dimensional computer rendering algorithms and display devices. Topics included: Geometric transformations, homogeneous coordinates, anti-aliasing, color vision, ray tracing, surface modeling, texture mapping, polyhedral representations, and reflectance models.
Machine Intelligence.name: Computer Graphics

Machine Intelligence.description: Embedded Operating Systems or Real time operating systems are operating systems are designed to be compact, efficient, and reliable. Topics discussed include embedded architectures, interaction with devices, concurrency, real-time principles, implementation trade-offs, profiling and code optimization, embedded software.
Machine Intelligence.name: Embedded Operating Systems

Machine Intelligence.description: This course discusses server based operating systems which are deployed, administered and managed via remote locations. Emphasis is placed upon the hardware required for interconnecting digital devices for the purpose of enabling data communication through a network. Bus architectures, ports, network cards, cabling, routers, switches are also covered. Ensuring network reliability and optimizing network performance are presented.
Machine Intelligence.name: Distributed Information Systems

Machine Intelligence.description: The study of integrated multi-medium communication networks, examining multiplexing schematics, switching circuit networks and packet switching networks. Communication traffic characterization, delay, blocking analysis and queuing network analysis will also be discussed. The course will also explore routing protocols, protocol architectures, network architectures, layered connection management, network design, path dimensioning, dynamic routing, flow control, and random access algorithms. Additionally, protocols for error control, signaling, addressing, fault management, and security control will be covered.
Machine Intelligence.name: Digital Communication Systems

Machine Intelligence.description: The use of Structured Query Language (SQL) and broad knowledge of database design, implementation, and systems development are presented in this course. Emphasis is places upon data modeling concepts, approaches and techniques, and stages in database development processes (conceptual, logical and physical design).
Machine Intelligence.name: Database 1

Machine Intelligence.description: The course introduces concepts of parallel algorithms analysis and implementation. Topics covered: shared memory model, distributed memory model, concurrency, synchronization, message passing interface (MPI), heterogeneous parallel programming, GPU programming.
Machine Intelligence.name: Introduction to Parallel and Distributed Computing

Machine Intelligence.description: This course covers the collaborative design and application of hybrid digital technology, devices, and systems.  Interfacing technologies, packaging electronics, and design considerations for modern devices, systems, and applications will also be discussed.  Some of the applications considered may include energy systems, mobile technology, sensor, networks, integrated rapid prototyping, and interfaces.
Machine Intelligence.name: Collaborative Digital and Hybrid System Design

Magnetics.description: This course covers the design of integrated circuits for use in analog applications as well as feedback of linear small-signal amplifiers, gain, and frequency response. Students will identify appropriate standards for solid state amplifiers and sub circuits and then design, simulate, construct and test them to meet the stated specifications.
Magnetics.name: Analog Electronics

Magnetics.description: This course is an introduction to the internal operation, terminal characteristics, and material physics of semi-conductors. Transistors, diode models and applications are also discussed. Principles of semiconductor devices and microelectronic circuits will be examined, along with the characteristics of diodes, multi-junction devices, metal oxide semiconductors and Field Effect Transistor based devices.
Magnetics.name: Electronic Devices

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2049 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2 illustrates the practical applications of Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Physics 2 Laboratory

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: Introduction to the artistic experience through the examination of different ideas, approaches and purposes of art. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Art Appreciation

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course is an introduction to the nature of philosophy, philosophical thinking, major intellectual movements in the history of philosophy, and specific problems in philosophy. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Introduction to Philosophy

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This is an intermediate programming course designed for students with prior programming experience in any language. It revises the fundamental programming concepts focusing on best practices in designing and writing efficient code. It also covers basic user-defined data types and the use of essential built-in data structures. After completing the course, students will have a solid command of computer programming and will be able to write medium-sized computer code.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Computer Programming 1

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This lecture-lab combined course introduces the fundamentals of transient state analysis; linear circuit analysis in frequency domain, sinusoidal steady-state analysis and power calculations, Laplace transform techniques, frequency response analysis, balanced three-phase circuits and two-port circuit analysis.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Circuits 2

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: The relationship between differential equations and initial conditions to physical problems in engineering, physics, technology and other applied areas is discussed. Students will be able to formulate, solve, and analyze the results of mathematical models of elementary physical problems and apply them. Topics include: first-order ordinary differential equations, theory of linear ordinary differential equations, solution of linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients, the Laplace transform and its application to solving linear ordinary differential equations.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Differential Equations

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course covers probability, random variables, hypothesis testing, confidence interval estimation, small sample methods, correlation, simple linear regression, and nonparametric statistics.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Statistics 1

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course presents a survey of the emergence of modern America as an industrial and world power; the Progressive Era; WWI; the Great Depression and the New Deal; WW II; and the Cold War era. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: American History Since 1877

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: An introduction to the basic principles, theories, and methods of psychology surveying the various areas of psychology.  This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: General Psychology

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course covers the design of integrated circuits for use in analog applications as well as feedback of linear small-signal amplifiers, gain, and frequency response. Students will identify appropriate standards for solid state amplifiers and sub circuits and then design, simulate, construct and test them to meet the stated specifications.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Analog Electronics

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course is an introduction to the internal operation, terminal characteristics, and material physics of semi-conductors. Transistors, diode models and applications are also discussed. Principles of semiconductor devices and microelectronic circuits will be examined, along with the characteristics of diodes, multi-junction devices, metal oxide semiconductors and Field Effect Transistor based devices.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Electronic Devices

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: Continuous-time and discrete-time systems analysis, focusing on linear time-invariant (LTI) systems and the classification of these systems is presented in this course. Convolution and its application to LTI systems, the Laplace, Fourier, and z transforms, the Fourier series and their application to the analysis of LTI systems will also be presented. Industry applications will be a specific focus.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Systems and Signals

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: The analysis and design of sequential logic circuits, combinational logic circuits, and feedback circuits are covered in this course. Additional topics include Boolean algebra, Boolean functions, number systems, minimizations, binary arithmetic, k-maps, combinational circuit synthesis, combinational medium scale integrated (MSI) logic circuits, sequential logic, sequential MSI logic circuits and synchronous state machine design.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Digital Logic Design

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This is a design course sequence for students with at least junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Design 1

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course focuses on the implementation of logic devices, MOSFET's, and BJT's. Students will analyze logic families including NMOS, CMOS, and TTL. The fundamentals of digital memory circuits are also covered.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Digital Electronics

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course covers static electric and magnetic fields, electric circuits, Maxwell's equations, radiation and propagation of electromagnetic waves.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Electromagnetic Fields and Applications

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: The course covers the design, development and application of hybrid devices and systems. It also introduces technologies and design criteria for hybrid devices and systems.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Hybrid Devices and Systems

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This is a design course for students with junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Design 2

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course discusses planning, controlling, and evaluating technology and engineering projects. Topics include modeling, project organization, risk analysis, technical forecasting, time and cost estimation and accommodation, and resource allocation and leveling. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Engineering & Technology Project Management

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: Semiconductor fundamentals, pn diodes, bipolar transistors, Schottky diodes, heterojunctions, JFETs, MESFETs, and MOSFETs are presented in this course.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Physical Electronics

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: In this course you will study digital signal processing, sampling and quantization, A/D & D/A converters, discrete time systems, convolution, z-transforms, transfer functions, digital filter realizations, fast Fourier transforms and analog & digital filter design.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Digital Signal Processing

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: The study of integrated multi-medium communication networks, examining multiplexing schematics, switching circuit networks and packet switching networks. Communication traffic characterization, delay, blocking analysis and queuing network analysis will also be discussed. The course will also explore routing protocols, protocol architectures, network architectures, layered connection management, network design, path dimensioning, dynamic routing, flow control, and random access algorithms. Additionally, protocols for error control, signaling, addressing, fault management, and security control will be covered.
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Digital Communication Systems

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: Classroom theory will be integrated with a participatory and experiential learning and work experience in business, industry, government and other technology-oriented areas of student interest. Evaluation by work supervisor is required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal, and a post-internship report are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Internship

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course discusses entrepreneurship, engineering, and technology development that accounts for society's growing needs for sustainability in all aspects of our infrastructure and society.  Entrepreneurship plays a key role in how these technologies are deployed and made accessible, while supporting appropriate and fair opportunities for economic development (capacity building).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Sustainability for Engineering, Technology, and Entrepreneurship

Digital and Hybrid Systems.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Digital and Hybrid Systems.name: Design 3

Electrodynamics.description: This course covers stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.
Electrodynamics.name: Chemistry 1

Electrodynamics.description: Students will participate in laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2045. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Electrodynamics.name: Chemistry 1 Laboratory

Electrodynamics.description: This foundation course is an introduction to engineering and addresses: ethics and professional responsibility, creative thinking, software and calculator techniques, time and project management, and technical report presentation and writing. Students will have opportunities to interact with engineering professionals. In the combined lab, teams will build and test various devices and report findings on paper, in verbal presentations, and by using various computer applications.
Electrodynamics.name: Introduction to Engineering

Electrodynamics.description: This course focuses on codes of ethics and moral reasoning, ethics and professionalism, the impact of engineering and technology problems/solutions/mistakes, engineering and technology as social experimentation, professional responsibilities and rights. Environmental and global issues are also discussed.
Electrodynamics.name: Ethics

Electrodynamics.description: This course focuses on the principal elements of writing clearly, efficiently and effectively. Logical arguments, building research skills and developing critical thinking through reading, writing and discussion are also presented. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Electrodynamics.name: English Composition 1: Expository and Argumentative Writing

Electrodynamics.description: This course is an introduction to analytic geometry; limits; continuity; differentiation of algebraic, trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions; applications of the derivative; inverse trigonometric functions; differentials; introduction to integration; and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
Electrodynamics.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1

Electrodynamics.description: This course is an introduction to computational thinking and the art of computer programming. Students will learn fundamental programming concepts and systematic design techniques. They will use them to write programs that computationally solve and reduce problems. At the end of the course, students will be able to use a programming language without focusing on the language specifics. No prior programming background is required and a working knowledge of high school level algebra is expected. This course is a prerequisite for all subsequent programming courses and is designed for all majors at both colleges.
Electrodynamics.name: Introduction to Computation and Programming

Electrodynamics.description: This foundation course provides a first look at engineering design and focuses on creativity, teamwork, communication, leadership, and work across engineering disciplines. Students will participate in a design-build-test project. Teams are required to give verbal and written technical and managerial reports.
Electrodynamics.name: Introduction to Engineering Design

Electrodynamics.description: This course focuses on the forms, formats, and genres of business, government, professional, and technical communication. Students are given opportunities to practice creating proposals, reports, applications, and resumes. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Electrodynamics.name: Technical Writing

Electrodynamics.description: Techniques of integration; applications of integration; differentiation and integration of inverse trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions; sequences and series are presented in this class.
Electrodynamics.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2

Electrodynamics.description: This is the first of a two-semester sequence of physics for technology and engineering. The course covers Newtonian mechanics and includes motion, vectors, Newton's laws, work and conservation of energy, systems of particles, collisions, equilibrium, oscillations, thermodynamics and waves.
Electrodynamics.name: Physics 1

Electrodynamics.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2048 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1 provides practical applications of Newtonian mechanics.
Electrodynamics.name: Physics 1 Laboratory

Electrodynamics.description: This lecture-lab combined course covers the basic analysis of linear circuits.  Topics include electrical quantities, network laws and theorems, steady state and transient analysis for circuits.  Computer-aided analysis is also covered.

Electrodynamics.description: This course covers solid analytic geometry, vectors, partial derivatives and multiple integrals.
