Multifunctional Materials.description: This course is an introduction to the nature of philosophy, philosophical thinking, major intellectual movements in the history of philosophy, and specific problems in philosophy. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Introduction to Philosophy

Multifunctional Materials.description: This is an intermediate programming course designed for students with prior programming experience in any language. It revises the fundamental programming concepts focusing on best practices in designing and writing efficient code. It also covers basic user-defined data types and the use of essential built-in data structures. After completing the course, students will have a solid command of computer programming and will be able to write medium-sized computer code.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Computer Programming 1

Multifunctional Materials.description: Basic approaches for modeling and solving operation efficiency challenges, and predicting and demonstrating cost-savings or other value-added gains.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Operations Research

Multifunctional Materials.description: An introduction to the techniques for creating solid models of engineering designs. Topics include three-dimensional modeling of parts and assemblies, visualization, orthographic and isometric free-hand sketching, and computer-generated design documentation. Industry applications will be a specific focus.
Multifunctional Materials.name: CAD

Multifunctional Materials.description: The relationship between differential equations and initial conditions to physical problems in engineering, physics, technology and other applied areas is discussed. Students will be able to formulate, solve, and analyze the results of mathematical models of elementary physical problems and apply them. Topics include: first-order ordinary differential equations, theory of linear ordinary differential equations, solution of linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients, the Laplace transform and its application to solving linear ordinary differential equations.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Differential Equations

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course presents a survey of the emergence of modern America as an industrial and world power; the Progressive Era; WWI; the Great Depression and the New Deal; WW II; and the Cold War era. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: American History Since 1877

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Multifunctional Materials.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Multifunctional Materials.description: An introduction to the basic principles, theories, and methods of psychology surveying the various areas of psychology.  This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: General Psychology

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers the equilibrium of particles frames, machine, trusses and rigid bodies in two and three dimensions using vector algebra.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Statics

Multifunctional Materials.description: This is a design course sequence for students with at least junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Design 1

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course provides an inductive learning approach towards theory and operation of instrumentation and characterization tools. Processes for inferring experimental values, error in the system and other mechanisms are covered. Additional topics include sample preparation and handling procedures, the principles of designing experiments, validation of methods and the business aspects of purchasing instruments. Emphasis is placed upon proper interpretation of data from experiments and communicating results.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Introduction to Instrumentation and Characterization

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course will cover how to engineer materials to achieve desired functions. Computational modeling approaches for optimizing materials properties and designs will be covered.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Multifunctional Materials

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers probability, random variables, hypothesis testing, confidence interval estimation, small sample methods, correlation, simple linear regression, and nonparametric statistics.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Statistics 1

Multifunctional Materials.description: Topics include properties of materials; Mohr's Circle; Hooke's Law for isotopic materials; stress and strain; stress strain diagrams; design loads; safety and working stresses; Shear and moment diagrams; Beams of two materials; indeterminate axially-loaded members; torsional shearing stresses and loads; displacements; and flexural and transverse shear stresses.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Strength of Materials

Multifunctional Materials.description: This is a design course for students with junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Design 2

Multifunctional Materials.description: Introduction to the fundamental concepts of materials science, determining structure-processing-property relationships, and optimizing complex systems for maximum design attribute achievement. Additional topics include chemical kinetics and experimental design to determine material properties.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Materials, Science, Structure, and Property

Multifunctional Materials.description: The properties and behavior of fluids at rest and in motion are discussed in this course. Topics include fluid statics; transport theorem; flow of incompressible fluids; flow of real fluids in closed conduits, impulse and momentum; and fluid measurement.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Fluid Mechanics

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers the properties and processes of thermodynamics. Topics include the first and second laws of thermodynamics; entropy; Carnot Cycle and Brayton Cycle.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Thermodynamics

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers applied principals in Thermodynamics and Kinetics including: gas laws, kinetic theory, classical and statistical thermodynamics, and applications to solutions, phase equilibria, chemical equilibria, and electrochemistry.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Survey of Physical Chemistry

Multifunctional Materials.description: Classroom theory will be integrated with a participatory and experiential learning and work experience in business, industry, government and other technology-oriented areas of student interest. Evaluation by work supervisor is required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal, and a post-internship report are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Internship

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course discusses planning, controlling, and evaluating technology and engineering projects. Topics include modeling, project organization, risk analysis, technical forecasting, time and cost estimation and accommodation, and resource allocation and leveling. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Engineering & Technology Project Management

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course will explore how materials can contribute to more sustainable products and processes. Life cycle analysis, and optimizing competing design properties will also be covered.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Materials for Sustainability

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers the basic principles of conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Heat Transfer

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Design 3

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course is an open forum to discuss new technical topics of interest to engineering and technology students. Topics are variable and based upon new developments in engineering, technology, and science.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Engineering & Technology Special Topics

Multifunctional Materials.description: How nanomaterials are used in batteries, ultracapacitors, and solar cells. Theory of measurements used to evaluate energy storage devices. Overview of how devices are integrated into systems.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Nanotechnology and Materials for Energy Storage and Generation

Multifunctional Materials.description: The theory of advanced instrumentation techniques; standard protocols and validation of methods; maintaining routine instrumentation; and processes for procuring new instrumentation are covered in this course.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Advanced Nanoscale and Materials Instrumentation

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course introduces students of to the structural, electronic, optical, and magnetic properties of materials.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Introduction to Solid State Physics

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course is an introduction to the principles of financial accounting and focuses on wealth and income measurement and the preparation and interpretation of financial statements. The recording and reporting of financial activity, balance sheets, income statements, changes in equity, cash flows, underlying assets, liabilities, and equities are also presented.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Principles of Financial Accounting

Multifunctional Materials.description: Biologically inspired nanomaterials; using biology to synthesize nanomaterials; nanostructured biological materials; and survey of nanomedicine concepts are presented.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Bio-Nanotechnology with Laboratory

Multifunctional Materials.description: How a living cell \xe2\x80\x98sees' nanomaterial is presented in this course. Topics include surface interactions between nanomaterials and other materials; the chemical modification of surfaces; physics of surface interactions; and structure-property relationships derived from the nanoscale interface.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Nano Scale Interface with Lab

Multifunctional Materials.description: The course covers object-oriented software engineering, the software development life cycle, system specification, software design patterns, and the methods of software measurement and estimation.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Software Engineering

Multifunctional Materials.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Multifunctional Materials.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course discusses the benefit-cost analysis of business and public projects, programs, and regulations. Students will be provided opportunities to conduct a benefit-cost analysis and determine if a public benefit-cost analysis is accurate.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Benefit Cost Analysis

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers interdisciplinary micro/nano fabrication and processing technology, process design, theory and application for process integration, sensitivity processes, imaging and related testing.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Micro/Nano Fabrication and Characterization

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers the scientific principles and concepts of active video and embedded control. Students will have opportunities to apply these methods.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Active Video and Embedded Control

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course covers the collaborative design and application of hybrid digital technology, devices, and systems.  Interfacing technologies, packaging electronics, and design considerations for modern devices, systems, and applications will also be discussed.  Some of the applications considered may include energy systems, mobile technology, sensor, networks, integrated rapid prototyping, and interfaces.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Collaborative Digital and Hybrid System Design

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course discusses applications for digital systems, hybrid systems, integrated systems, embedded devices, interfaces, mobile devices for applications in unmanned vehicles, manufacturing, health technologies, infrastructure monitoring, energy systems, and sustainability. The applications will be associated with industry and research trends that guide application development, deployment, and innovation supporting entrepreneurship.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Hybrid Digital System Applications

Multifunctional Materials.description: This course considers logistics as part of a market-driven supply chain process. Sound decision making using analytical methods is discussed. Topics include management, outsourcing, warehouse management, forecasting, third party logistics and service providers, and performance measurement.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Logistics in the Supply Chain

Multifunctional Materials.description: Managing the supply chain in a global context including supplier selection, inventory, quality, and pricing are covered in this course. Customs, global sourcing, transportation and location are also covered.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Global Supply Chain Management

Multifunctional Materials.description: Advanced concepts in statistical analysis. Linear models and experimental design, multiple regression analysis, analysis of variance with multiple classification, analysis of covariance, repeated measures analysis of variance, multiple comparison techniques, and diagnostic procedures and transformations are discussed in this course.
Multifunctional Materials.name: Advanced Quantitative Methods

Nanotechnology.description: This course covers stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.
Nanotechnology.name: Chemistry 1

Nanotechnology.description: Students will participate in laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2045. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Nanotechnology.name: Chemistry 1 Laboratory

Nanotechnology.description: This course focuses on the principal elements of writing clearly, efficiently and effectively. Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Circuits 1

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers solid analytic geometry, vectors, partial derivatives and multiple integrals.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 3

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: The second of a two-semester sequence of physics for scientists and engineers. Content includes Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Physics 2

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2049 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2 illustrates the practical applications of Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Physics 2 Laboratory

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course presents a survey of the emergence of modern America as an industrial and world power; the Progressive Era; WWI; the Great Depression and the New Deal; WW II; and the Cold War era. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: American History Since 1877

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: An introduction to the basic principles, theories, and methods of psychology surveying the various areas of psychology.  This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: General Psychology

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This is an intermediate programming course designed for students with prior programming experience in any language. It revises the fundamental programming concepts focusing on best practices in designing and writing efficient code. It also covers basic user-defined data types and the use of essential built-in data structures. After completing the course, students will have a solid command of computer programming and will be able to write medium-sized computer code.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Computer Programming 1

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Basic approaches for modeling and solving operation efficiency challenges, and predicting and demonstrating cost-savings or other value-added gains.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Operations Research

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: An introduction to the techniques for creating solid models of engineering designs. Topics include three-dimensional modeling of parts and assemblies, visualization, orthographic and isometric free-hand sketching, and computer-generated design documentation. Industry applications will be a specific focus.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: CAD

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: The relationship between differential equations and initial conditions to physical problems in engineering, physics, technology and other applied areas is discussed. Students will be able to formulate, solve, and analyze the results of mathematical models of elementary physical problems and apply them. Topics include: first-order ordinary differential equations, theory of linear ordinary differential equations, solution of linear ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients, the Laplace transform and its application to solving linear ordinary differential equations.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Differential Equations

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Introduction to the artistic experience through the examination of different ideas, approaches and purposes of art. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Art Appreciation

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course is an introduction to the nature of philosophy, philosophical thinking, major intellectual movements in the history of philosophy, and specific problems in philosophy. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Introduction to Philosophy

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers the equilibrium of particles frames, machine, trusses and rigid bodies in two and three dimensions using vector algebra.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Statics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This is a design course sequence for students with at least junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Design 1

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course provides an inductive learning approach towards theory and operation of instrumentation and characterization tools. Processes for inferring experimental values, error in the system and other mechanisms are covered. Additional topics include sample preparation and handling procedures, the principles of designing experiments, validation of methods and the business aspects of purchasing instruments. Emphasis is placed upon proper interpretation of data from experiments and communicating results.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Introduction to Instrumentation and Characterization

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers modeling and simulation including continuum methods, atomistic and molecular simulation as well as quantum mechanics. Students will have opportunities to apply these methods. Additional topics include modeling & simulation development process, fidelity, accuracy, and resolution of models, verification & validation, systems modeling language (SysML), simulation methodologies, system engineering life cycle, simulation ROI, and standards.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Collaborative Simulation

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers probability, random variables, hypothesis testing, confidence interval estimation, small sample methods, correlation, simple linear regression, and nonparametric statistics.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Statistics 1

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Topics include properties of materials; Mohr's Circle; Hooke's Law for isotopic materials; stress and strain; stress strain diagrams; design loads; safety and working stresses; Shear and moment diagrams; Beams of two materials; indeterminate axially-loaded members; torsional shearing stresses and loads; displacements; and flexural and transverse shear stresses.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Strength of Materials

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This is a design course for students with junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Design 2

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Introduction to the fundamental concepts of materials science, determining structure-processing-property relationships, and optimizing complex systems for maximum design attribute achievement. Additional topics include chemical kinetics and experimental design to determine material properties.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Materials, Science, Structure, and Property

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers the properties and processes of thermodynamics. Topics include the first and second laws of thermodynamics; entropy; Carnot Cycle and Brayton Cycle.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Thermodynamics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers the scientific principles and concepts of active video and embedded control. Students will have opportunities to apply these methods.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Active Video and Embedded Control

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: The basics of information mapping, scientific visualization, and information visualization for analytical reasoning are covered in this course.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Information Mapping, Visualization and Characterization

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Classroom theory will be integrated with a participatory and experiential learning and work experience in business, industry, government and other technology-oriented areas of student interest. Evaluation by work supervisor is required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal, and a post-internship report are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Internship

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: The properties and behavior of fluids at rest and in motion are discussed in this course. Topics include fluid statics; transport theorem; flow of incompressible fluids; flow of real fluids in closed conduits, impulse and momentum; and fluid measurement.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Fluid Mechanics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers the basic principles of conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Heat Transfer

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Design 3

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course discusses planning, controlling, and evaluating technology and engineering projects. Topics include modeling, project organization, risk analysis, technical forecasting, time and cost estimation and accommodation, and resource allocation and leveling. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Engineering & Technology Project Management

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course is an open forum to discuss new technical topics of interest to engineering and technology students. Topics are variable and based upon new developments in engineering, technology, and science.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Engineering & Technology Special Topics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course introduces students to current and future trends in logistics technology, policy, and sustainability. Topics include resource sustainability, environmental impacts of existing and emerging technologies and local environmental conditions and the global climate.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Sustainable Logistics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course is an introduction to the principles of financial accounting and focuses on wealth and income measurement and the preparation and interpretation of financial statements. The recording and reporting of financial activity, balance sheets, income statements, changes in equity, cash flows, underlying assets, liabilities, and equities are also presented.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Principles of Financial Accounting

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Biologically inspired nanomaterials; using biology to synthesize nanomaterials; nanostructured biological materials; and survey of nanomedicine concepts are presented.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Bio-Nanotechnology with Laboratory

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: How a living cell \xe2\x80\x98sees' nanomaterial is presented in this course. Topics include surface interactions between nanomaterials and other materials; the chemical modification of surfaces; physics of surface interactions; and structure-property relationships derived from the nanoscale interface.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Nano Scale Interface with Lab

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: The course covers object-oriented software engineering, the software development life cycle, system specification, software design patterns, and the methods of software measurement and estimation.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Software Engineering

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course discusses the benefit-cost analysis of business and public projects, programs, and regulations. Students will be provided opportunities to conduct a benefit-cost analysis and determine if a public benefit-cost analysis is accurate.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Benefit Cost Analysis

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers interdisciplinary micro/nano fabrication and processing technology, process design, theory and application for process integration, sensitivity processes, imaging and related testing.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Micro/Nano Fabrication and Characterization

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers the scientific principles and concepts of active video and embedded control. Students will have opportunities to apply these methods.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Active Video and Embedded Control

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course covers the collaborative design and application of hybrid digital technology, devices, and systems.  Interfacing technologies, packaging electronics, and design considerations for modern devices, systems, and applications will also be discussed.  Some of the applications considered may include energy systems, mobile technology, sensor, networks, integrated rapid prototyping, and interfaces.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Collaborative Digital and Hybrid System Design

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course discusses applications for digital systems, hybrid systems, integrated systems, embedded devices, interfaces, mobile devices for applications in unmanned vehicles, manufacturing, health technologies, infrastructure monitoring, energy systems, and sustainability. The applications will be associated with industry and research trends that guide application development, deployment, and innovation supporting entrepreneurship.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Hybrid Digital System Applications

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: This course considers logistics as part of a market-driven supply chain process. Sound decision making using analytical methods is discussed. Topics include management, outsourcing, warehouse management, forecasting, third party logistics and service providers, and performance measurement.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Logistics in the Supply Chain

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Managing the supply chain in a global context including supplier selection, inventory, quality, and pricing are covered in this course. Customs, global sourcing, transportation and location are also covered.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Global Supply Chain Management

Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.description: Advanced concepts in statistical analysis. Linear models and experimental design, multiple regression analysis, analysis of variance with multiple classification, analysis of covariance, repeated measures analysis of variance, multiple comparison techniques, and diagnostic procedures and transformations are discussed in this course.
Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.name: Advanced Quantitative Methods

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This is an introductory level course intended to prepare students for the more complex courses they will encounter in their academic careers, by introducing foundational  technology concepts and principles. The course is also intended to orient students to the various majors and concentration tracks in the I & T College.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Introduction to Innovation and Technology

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This foundation course is an introduction to engineering and addresses: ethics and professional responsibility, creative thinking, software and calculator techniques, time and project management, and technical report presentation and writing. Students will have opportunities to interact with engineering professionals. In the combined lab, teams will build and test various devices and report findings on paper, in verbal presentations, and by using various computer applications.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Introduction to Engineering

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course focuses on the principal elements of writing clearly, efficiently and effectively. Logical arguments, building research skills and developing critical thinking through reading, writing and discussion are also presented. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: English Composition 1: Expository and Argumentative Writing

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Differential and integral single-variable calculus of algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions with an emphasis on applications. No credit for students with credit in MAC 2311.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Calculus 1

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Using technology to improve global business performance as well as the creation of value for organizations by using business process innovations and technology are discussed. Hardware concepts, operating systems, word processing, spread sheets, database, project management, networks, internet, World Wide Web, multimedia presentations, information systems, and other microcomputer hardware and software applications that are typically used in the work place are presented.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Applications for Business

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course focuses on the forms, formats, and genres of business, government, professional, and technical communication. Students are given opportunities to practice creating proposals, reports, applications, and resumes. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Technical Writing

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course is an introduction to the processes and functions of logistics, materials, and supply chain management and focuses on creating a competitive advantage.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Introduction to Logistics, Materials and Supply Chain Management

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course covers probability, random variables, hypothesis testing, confidence interval estimation, small sample methods, correlation, simple linear regression, and nonparametric statistics.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Statistics 1

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course is an introduction to the principles of financial accounting and focuses on wealth and income measurement and the preparation and interpretation of financial statements. The recording and reporting of financial activity, balance sheets, income statements, changes in equity, cash flows, underlying assets, liabilities, and equities are also presented.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Principles of Financial Accounting

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: The Structure of the legal system; administrative law and government regulation of business; and the legal environment of business including constitutional law, torts, contracts, and product liability are presented.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Law, Public Policy, Negotiation and Business

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course covers tools used by management for cost reporting and control including statements, analytical tools, and reports.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Principles of Managerial Accounting

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This is an intermediate level course intended to prepare students for legal and ethical issues they will encounter in their professional careers and student internships. The course focuses on management oriented technology issues in the legal and business environment, professionalism, and the impact of technology on society. The course also covers service-based learning.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Legal, Ethical, and Management Issues in Technology

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course discusses planning, controlling, and evaluating technology and engineering projects. Topics include modeling, project organization, risk analysis, technical forecasting, time and cost estimation and accommodation, and resource allocation and leveling. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Engineering & Technology Project Management

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This is a design course sequence for students with at least junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Design 1

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Enterprises, markets, institutions, firm competitiveness, industry globalization, international business transactions, and entry strategies are discussed from a cross-cultural and international perspective.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: International & Comparative Dimensions of Business

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Strategies, techniques, and tools for process improvement resulting in continuous efforts to achieve stable and predictable results are covered in this class.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Six Sigma

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course considers logistics as part of a market-driven supply chain process. Sound decision making using analytical methods is discussed. Topics include management, outsourcing, warehouse management, forecasting, third party logistics and service providers, and performance measurement.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Logistics in the Supply Chain

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Communication with media and government as well as media management is presented.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Logistics, Materials and Supply Management Communications

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This is a design course for students with junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Design 2

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Applying Six Sigma to business including managing processes, process improvement and control, and toolset application are covered in this course.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Six Sigma Applications

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Managing the supply chain in a global context including supplier selection, inventory, quality, and pricing are covered in this course. Customs, global sourcing, transportation and location are also covered.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Global Supply Chain Management

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course provides an overview of Supply chain security and risk management (SCSRM). Supply chain security in relationship to homeland security is discussed. Topics include security organizations, legislation, first response and recovery, as well as security related to maritime, container cargo, land transportation, food chain, pharmaceutical, utilities, and cyber security.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Supply Chain Risk Management

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course discusses the creation of supply chain strategies focusing upon management, production, logistics and enterprise solutions.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Supply Chain Strategy

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Classroom theory will be integrated with a participatory and experiential learning and work experience in business, industry, government and other technology-oriented areas of student interest. Evaluation by work supervisor is required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal, and a post-internship report are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Internship

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course introduces students to current and future trends in logistics technology, policy, and sustainability. Topics include resource sustainability, environmental impacts of existing and emerging technologies and local environmental conditions and the global climate.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Sustainable Logistics

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course covers strategic and tactical supply chain research and negotiations.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Supply Chain Management Research and Negotiation

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Enterprise, material requirement, and manufacturing resource planning as well as computer integrated manufacturing are covered in this course.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Planning and Control Systems for Supply Chain Management

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Procurement, contracting cycle, methods of purchasing, source selection, receipt, inspection, and quality assurance are covered in this course. Inventory, physical distribution, surplus, salvage, and disposal are also discussed.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Purchasing and Materials Management

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course discusses the benefit-cost analysis of business and public projects, programs, and regulations. Students will be provided opportunities to conduct a benefit-cost analysis and determine if a public benefit-cost analysis is accurate.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Benefit Cost Analysis

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Design 3

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Route planning, enterprise real estate, as well as supply chain, workforce and all-channel commerce software are discussed in this class.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Logistics and Supply Chain Management Computer Software

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: This course discusses relationships with suppliers and customers, quality management, process improvement, and cost analysis.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Quality Management

Materials and Supply Chain Management.description: Students will apply Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) to commercial business and government life cycles. Strategic procurement, loss of sources, elimination of reactive actions, mitigation, solution paths, system inoperability avoidance, long-term proactive solution paths, redesign and replacement, and costs are covered in this course.
Materials and Supply Chain Management.name: Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages

Logistics.description: This is an introductory level course intended to prepare students for the more complex courses they will encounter in their academic careers, by introducing foundational  technology concepts and principles. Logistics.name: Global Logistics Management

Logistics.description: This course covers air transportation including major, regional, cargo, and general carriers.
Logistics.name: Air Transportation and Operations

This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Logistics.name: Internship

Logistics.description: In this course forward-moving logistics is compared to reverse-moving logistics. Both goods and information are discussed. Topics include federal and state regulations, waste management, recycled materials, technology, financial controls, stakeholders, and performance measurement.
Logistics.name: Reverse Logistics

Logistics.description: This course provides an overview of the use of technology (bar codes, GPS, and Radio Frequency Identification tags) in logistics to control recalls, returns, recycling, and waste management. Management functions, Data synchronization, and interrelationships between different technologies to capture data regarding products moving in a logistics system are also discussed.
Logistics.name: Logistics and Technology

Logistics.description: This course presents the packaging, transport, storage and delivery of hazardous materials. The Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) impact is also considered
Logistics.name: Hazardous Materials Management & Transportation

Logistics.description: This course discusses the benefit-cost analysis of business and public projects, programs, and regulations. Students will be provided opportunities to conduct a benefit-cost analysis and determine if a public benefit-cost analysis is accurate.
Logistics.name: Benefit Cost Analysis

Logistics.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Logistics.name: Design 3

Logistics.description: Route planning, enterprise real estate, as well as supply chain, workforce and all-channel commerce software are discussed in this class.
Logistics.name: Logistics and Supply Chain Management Computer Software

Logistics.description: This advanced course focuses on management, continuity, risk, the environment, and manufacturing. The connection between research, development, innovation and the movement of new products is also discussed.
Logistics.name: Advanced Logistics Management

Logistics.description: Students will apply Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) to commercial business and government life cycles. Strategic procurement, loss of sources, elimination of reactive actions, mitigation, solution paths, system inoperability avoidance, long-term proactive solution paths, redesign and replacement, and costs are covered in this course.
Logistics.name: Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages

Cloud Virtualization.description: This is an introductory level course intended to prepare students for the more complex courses they will encounter in their academic careers, by introducing foundational  technology concepts and principles. The course is also intended to orient students to the various majors and concentration tracks in the I & T College.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Introduction to Innovation and Technology

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course focuses on the principal elements of writing clearly, efficiently and effectively. Logical arguments, building research skills and developing critical thinking through reading, writing and discussion are also presented. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: English Composition 1: Expository and Argumentative Writing

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course is an introduction to analytic geometry; limits; continuity; differentiation of algebraic, trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions; applications of the derivative; inverse trigonometric functions; differentials; introduction to integration; and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: In this course students will study the chemistry of life, cell structure and function, photosynthesis, cellular respiration genetics, evolution, and the diversity of life. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Biology 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: Students will participate in laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in BSC 1010. This course meets communication/ writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Biology 1 Laboratory

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course covers stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, the states of matter, reaction rates and equilibria.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Chemistry 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: Students will participate in laboratory experiments designed to reflect the topics presented in CHM 2045. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Chemistry 1 Laboratory

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course is an introduction to computational thinking and the art of computer programming. Students will learn fundamental programming concepts and systematic design techniques. They will use them to write programs that computationally solve and reduce problems. At the end of the course, students will be able to use a programming language without focusing on the language specifics. No prior programming background is required and a working knowledge of high school level algebra is expected. This course is a prerequisite for all subsequent programming courses and is designed for all majors at both colleges.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Introduction to Computation and Programming

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course focuses on the forms, formats, and genres of business, government, professional, and technical communication. Students are given opportunities to practice creating proposals, reports, applications, and resumes. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Technical Writing

Cloud Virtualization.description: Techniques of integration; applications of integration; differentiation and integration of inverse trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions; sequences and series are presented in this class.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2

Cloud Virtualization.description: This is the first of a two-semester sequence of physics for technology and engineering. The course covers Newtonian mechanics and includes motion, vectors, Newton's laws, work and conservation of energy, systems of particles, collisions, equilibrium, oscillations, thermodynamics and waves.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Physics 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2048 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 1 provides practical applications of Newtonian mechanics.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Physics 1 Laboratory

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course is a weekly seminar designed to support freshman students in their transition to college. Meetings are held in and out of class for students to bring up any personal, academic or administrative concerns they have during their first semester in college. For the more advanced students, this course offers mentorship for those who wish to work on complex problems and projects early in their academic careers.
Cloud Virtualization.name: First Year Experience

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course covers the concepts of knowledge management (KM), knowledge discovery (KD), data analytics, and information retrieval (IR). This is an introductory level course designed to familiarize students with the principles and fundamentals of information science theories and methods. The course is intended to introduce and explain foundations that students will need to be able to use and master in their upper level courses, internships and careers.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Fundamentals of Applied Information

Cloud Virtualization.description: This is an intermediate programming course designed for students with prior programming experience in any language. It revises the fundamental programming concepts focusing on best practices in designing and writing efficient code. It also covers basic user-defined data types and the use of essential built-in data structures. After completing the course, students will have a solid command of computer programming and will be able to write medium-sized computer code.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Computer Programming 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course discusses logic, sets, functions, algorithms and complexity, integers and algorithms, mathematical reasoning and induction, counting principles, permutations and combinations, discrete probability, advanced counting techniques and inclusion-exclusion.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Discrete Mathematics

Cloud Virtualization.description: The second of a two-semester sequence of physics for scientists and engineers. Content includes Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Physics 2

Cloud Virtualization.description: This laboratory experience for PHY 2049 Physics with Analytic Geometry and Calculus 2 illustrates the practical applications of Coulomb's law, electric fields and potentials, capacitance, currents and circuits, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, ray optics, interference and diffraction.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Physics 2 Laboratory

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course presents a survey of the emergence of modern America as an industrial and world power; the Progressive Era; WWI; the Great Depression and the New Deal; WW II; and the Cold War era. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: American History Since 1877

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Cloud Virtualization.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Cloud Virtualization.description: An introduction to the basic principles, theories, and methods of psychology surveying the various areas of psychology.  This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: General Psychology

Cloud Virtualization.description: The course introduces program run-time analysis and algorithm design and analysis. Topics include: data abstraction principals, serial and parallel data structures, linked lists, graphs, trees, divide and conquer algorithms, greedy algorithms, and linear programming.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Data Structures & Algorithms

Cloud Virtualization.description: The use of Structured Query Language (SQL) and broad knowledge of database design, implementation, and systems development are presented in this course. Emphasis is places upon data modeling concepts, approaches and techniques, and stages in database development processes (conceptual, logical and physical design).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Database 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course presents the nature of economic aggregates such as investment, employment, and price levels. The interrelationship of business and government policies; applicability of economic theory to the problems of business forecasting; cyclical fluctuations and long-term economic trends are also examined. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Principles of Macroeconomics

Cloud Virtualization.description: Theories of production, determination of prices and distribution of income in regulated and unregulated industries are discussed. Attention is also given to industrial relations, monopolies and comparative economic systems. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Principles of Microeconomics

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course covers probability, random variables, hypothesis testing, confidence interval estimation, small sample methods, correlation, simple linear regression, and nonparametric statistics.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Statistics 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: Introduction to the artistic experience through the examination of different ideas, approaches and purposes of art. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Art Appreciation

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course is an introduction to the nature of philosophy, philosophical thinking, major intellectual movements in the history of philosophy, and specific problems in philosophy. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Introduction to Philosophy

Cloud Virtualization.description: This advanced course covers critical thinking and problem solving techniques applied to information systems. Fundamentals and complexities associated with learning and applying the methods for creating a system development and implementation (S-DIP) plan are also covered. The course includes materials and exercises for students to develop skills in the domain of systems acquisition, integration, and implementation through applied system development and planning, and application lifecycle management.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Systems Acquisition, Integration and Implementation

Cloud Virtualization.description: This is an intermediate level course intended to prepare students for legal and ethical issues they will encounter in their professional careers and student internships. The course focuses on management oriented technology issues in the legal and business environment, professionalism, and the impact of technology on society. The course also covers service-based learning.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Legal, Ethical, and Management Issues in Technology

Cloud Virtualization.description: This is a design course sequence for students with at least junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Design 1

Cloud Virtualization.description: Advanced concepts in statistical analysis. Linear models and experimental design, multiple regression analysis, analysis of variance with multiple classification, analysis of covariance, repeated measures analysis of variance, multiple comparison techniques, and diagnostic procedures and transformations are discussed in this course.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Advanced Quantitative Methods

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course discusses the background and principles of computer architecture and assembly language including the following: computer organization, computer performance, assembly language and machine code, computer arithmetic, multi-processor and distributed architectures, ALU design, datapath and control, pipelining, memory hierarchy, I/O devices, graphics, mobile and multi-core processors.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Computer Architecture

Cloud Virtualization.description: Topics include: Client-side programming, distributed transactions, remote procedure calls, component objects, server side programming and network load balancing. Methods such as HTML5, CSS, JavaScript, XML, PHP, Python, and Ruby Rails are introduced.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Web Application Development

Cloud Virtualization.description: This is a design course for students with junior standing. Teams of students will design, build and test a solution to a real-world design problem appropriate to each student's program of study. Students will demonstrate the solution they develop at the end of the course. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Design 2

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course discusses planning, controlling, and evaluating technology and engineering projects. Topics include modeling, project organization, risk analysis, technical forecasting, time and cost estimation and accommodation, and resource allocation and leveling. Verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Engineering & Technology Project Management

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course introduces students to the paradigm of Design Science and the Information Systems Research Cycle (ISRC). Students will learn to apply ISRC to solve real business problems via the IT Artifact using methods, models and theories to design, evaluate and deliver IT solutions. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Design Science

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course provides an introduction to fundamental concepts in computer networks, including their design and implementation. Topics covered include all seven layers of OSI Reference Model, network protocols (providing reliability and congestion control), routing, and link access. Special attention is also paid to wireless networks and security.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Introduction to Computer Networks

Cloud Virtualization.description: Fundamentals of data communication, including network architectures, communication protocols, transmission standards, internet, and distributed computing are covered. Basic concepts of network management systems, including fundamentals of standards, models, languages, network management systems architectures and protocols as well as SNMP based protocols that manage TCP/IP networks are also discussed. Broadband network management systems and Web-based network management systems tools and applications are presented.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Data Communication

Cloud Virtualization.description: Classroom theory will be integrated with a participatory and experiential learning and work experience in business, industry, government and other technology-oriented areas of student interest. Evaluation by work supervisor is required. Supervision by a faculty member or delegated authority, daily journal, and a post-internship report are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Internship

Cloud Virtualization.description: Access control systems, telecommunications and network security, security management practices, application and systems development security, cryptography, disaster recovery planning, legal and ethical issues, and physical security are covered in this course. Special topics include Network Security, Cryptography, Access Control, Security Architecture and Models, Applications and Systems Development, and Vulnerability Assessment.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Data Security

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course focuses on identifying and solving a business problem. Students will design individual projects with realistic constraints. The projects will be focused on providing experience in the practice and process of engineering design. Proficiency in all previous courses is required. Students will develop a solution to an open-ended engineering problem which will be demonstrated at the end of the course. A project proposal and verbal and written technical and managerial reports are also required. This course meets communication/writing-intensive requirements (W).
Cloud Virtualization.name: Design 3

Cloud Virtualization.description: This is an applied course in the principles, methods, and technologies of Cloud Computing. Upon completion of this course students should be able to create, configure, build, deploy and manage a variety of cloud based solutions.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Advanced Concepts in Virtualization

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course introduces tiered based architecture. Students will learn the fundamentals of the solution stack and how it impacts application development and system design.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Tiered Architecture and Solution Stack

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course discusses server based operating systems which are deployed, administered and managed via remote locations. Emphasis is placed upon the hardware required for interconnecting digital devices for the purpose of enabling data communication through a network. Bus architectures, ports, network cards, cabling, routers, switches are also covered. Ensuring network reliability and optimizing network performance are presented.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Distributed Information Systems

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course covers the concepts of the design and implementation of operating systems. Topics included: memory and storage management, virtual memory, processes/threads, system calls, interfaces, I/O, file system, and introduction to virtualization.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Operating Systems Concepts

Cloud Virtualization.description: This course discusses the strategic management of the cloud environment and considerations for leveraging cloud providers for Infrastructure as a Service (Iaas), Platform as a Service (Paas), and Software as a Service (SaaS). Course content emphasizes mechanisms for relating virtual resources to underlying physical resources, system monitoring, security administration, scalability, and cost analysis. Current and emerging cloud providers will be surveyed and analyzed in regard to implementing a specific cloud solution, use of contemporary cloud management tools, and articulating issues involved in migrating to a cloud environment are presented.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Cloud Implementation Strategies and Cloud Providers

Cloud Virtualization.description: The course explores Web Services Architecture and methods for implementing communication of systems and software over distributed networks. Topics include: Client-side programming, distributed transactions, remote procedure calls, component objects, server side programming and network load balancing.
Cloud Virtualization.name: Advanced Web Services

Big Data Analytics.description: This is an introductory level course intended to prepare students for the more complex courses they will encounter in their academic careers, by introducing foundational  technology concepts and principles.
